title: Agent
description: An agent definition specifying model, tools, and behavioral configuration.
$comment:
An agent is a directory containing an `AGENT.md` file with YAML frontmatter and an optional
Markdown body providing system instructions. Agents are discovered from two locations:
workspace `.stencila/agents/` and user config `~/.config/stencila/agents/`.

type.$comment: This is a special property analogous to JSON-LD's `@type` keyword.

id.$comment: This is a special property analogous to JSON-LD's `@id` keyword.

identifiers.description: Any kind of identifier for any kind of Thing.
identifiers.$comment:
Some identifiers have specific properties e.g the `issn` property for
the `Periodical` type. These should be used in preference to this
property which is intended for identifiers that do not yet have a
specific property. Identifiers can be represented as strings, but
using a `PropertyValue` will usually be better because it allows
for `propertyID` (i.e. the type of identifier).

name.$comment:
Must be lowercase kebab-case: 1-64 characters, only lowercase alphanumeric
and hyphens, no leading/trailing/consecutive hyphens. By convention, names
follow a `thing-role` pattern describing the agent's domain and function,
e.g. `code-engineer`, `code-reviewer`, `data-analyst`, `site-designer`.

workType.description: The type of `CreativeWork` (e.g. article, book, software application).

about.description: The subject matter of the content.
about.$comment:
Consistent with https://schema.org/about, this property allows for
linking to one of more `Thing` nodes. This could for example include
a `Person` (e.g for a bibliography) or a `DefinedTerm` (e.g. for
subject areas the creative work relates to).

abstract.description: A short description that summarizes a `CreativeWork`.

provenance.description: A summary of the provenance of the content within the work.

editors.$comment:
Note that, consistent with schema.org, this property can only include
a `Person`, unlike `authors` and `maintainers` which can also include
`Organization`.

maintainers.$comment:
A maintainer of a `Dataset`, `SoftwareApplication`, or other `CreativeWork`.
A maintainer is a `Person` or `Organization` that manages contributions to,
and/or publication of, some (typically complex) artifact. It is common for
distributions of software and data to be based on "upstream" sources.
When maintainer is applied to a specific version of something e.g. a particular
version or packaging of a Dataset, it is always possible that the upstream
source has a different maintainer. The `isBasedOn` property can be used to
indicate such relationships between datasets to make the different maintenance
roles clear. Similarly in the case of software, a package may have dedicated
maintainers working on integration into software distributions such as Ubuntu,
as well as upstream maintainers of the underlying work.

dateAccepted.$comment:
This is not yet a schema.org property but the term is used
[in Dublin Core](http://purl.org/dc/terms/dateAccepted).

funders.description: People or organizations that funded the `CreativeWork`.

fundedBy.description: Grants that funded the `CreativeWork`; reverse of `fundedItems`.
fundedBy.$comment:
This follows the proposal [here](https://github.com/schemaorg/schemaorg/issues/2258)
for a property that is the reverse of `fundedItems`.
It is an any because a `CreativeWork` may have been funded through more than
one `Grant`.

genre.description: Genre of the creative work, broadcast channel or group.

keywords.description: Keywords or tags used to describe this content. Multiple entries in a keywords list are typically delimited by commas.

isPartOf.description: An item or other CreativeWork that this CreativeWork is a part of.

licenses.description: License documents that applies to this content, typically indicated by URL, but may be a `CreativeWork` itself.

parts.description: Elements of the collection which can be a variety of different elements, such as Articles, Datatables, Tables and more.

bibliography.description: A bibliography of references which may be cited in the work.
bibliography.$comment:
Unlike `references` which contains only the references that are actually
cited in the work, `bibliography` is a database of all available references
loaded from an external source file at compile time. It is ephemeral and
not persisted when the document is saved.

references.description: References to other creative works, such as another publication, web page, scholarly article, etc.

text.description: The textual content of this creative work.

title.description: The title of the creative work.

repository.description: URL of the repository where the un-compiled, human readable source of the work is located.

path.description: The file system path of the source of the work.
path.$comment:
Usually only used when the work is within a Git (or other version control) repository,
and then is usually relative to the repository root.

commit.description: The commit hash (or similar) of the source of the work.
commit.$comment: Only used when the work's source file is within a Git (or other version control) repository.

version.description: The version of the creative work.
version.$comment:
In this case `string` is listed as an alternative before `number` to
avoid semantic version numbers e.g. `1.0` being parsed, and subsequently
encoded, as `1` thereby resulting in loss of information.

content.description: The content of the agent (the Markdown body providing system instructions).
content.$comment:
The Markdown body after the frontmatter contains the agent's system instructions.
This is optional â€” an agent may be configuration-only with no instructions.

model.$comment:
The model to use, e.g. "claude-sonnet-4-5", "gpt-5.2-codex". When not specified,
the default model for the provider is used.

provider.$comment:
The provider to use, e.g. "anthropic", "openai", "gemini". When not specified,
the first available provider is used.

allowedSkills.description: Skill names this agent can use.
allowedSkills.$comment:
When unset, all discovered skills are available to the agent.
When set, only the listed skills are available.

allowedTools.description: Tool names available to the agent.
allowedTools.$comment:
Experimental per the spec. In the spec this is a space-delimited string named
`allowed-tools`; we parse it into an array of strings for easier programmatic use.

reasoningEffort.description: Reasoning effort level for the agent.
reasoningEffort.$comment:
Valid values are "low", "medium", "high", or a custom provider-specific value.
When not specified, the provider's default is used.

toolTimeout.description: Default timeout for tool execution in seconds.

maxToolRounds.description: Maximum tool-call rounds per user input.

compatibility.$comment:
Max 500 characters. Indicates intended product, required system packages,
network access needs, etc. Most agents do not need this field.
